Title.evidence: A Double-Blind Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Minimally Invasive and Classic Approaches in Total Hip Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to MIS or CLASS groups using a block-randomised, stratified method

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a single center, this double-blind, randomised controlled trial enrolled 120 patients eligible for primary noncemented THA

Intervention.evidence: Minimally invasive surgery (MIS) for total hip arthroplasty (THA) is hypothesized to offer faster rehabilitation due to smaller incisions and reduced muscle dissection compared to the classic approach (CLASS).

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the clinical outcomes of MIS versus CLASS.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Harris Hip Score (HHS) at 6 weeks postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to MIS or CLASS groups using a block-randomised, stratified method

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for patients and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Conducted at a single center, this double-blind, randomised controlled trial enrolled 120 patients eligible for primary noncemented THA from January 2005 to November 2007.

Result_Outcome.evidence: At 6 weeks, the MIS group demonstrated a statistically significant increase in mean HHS compared to the CLASS group (mean difference = 4.5, 95% CI 0.5 to 8.5; p = 0.03)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events included six complications in the MIS group and two in the CLASS group.
